Triggering Event: At an art gallery opening, where his work hung alongside peers, he noticed a group of young patrons laughing softly around one of his abstract pieces. One whispered, "My kid could paint that," loud enough for him to hear. He felt heat rise in his face as they walked away, leaving him alone with the mocking painting and his silent humiliation.
Generated Assessment: He couldn't help but think, "Well, this is exactly how my life goes - I'm stuck in galleries, surrounded by people who don't understand me, while everyone else has success beyond my wildest dreams." The memory of his own childhood, where he was constantly belittled and ridiculed by his parents for his lack of talent, flooded his mind. It seemed like fate had already decided his path, and now he was just along for the ride. This wasn't the first time he'd experienced such rejection, but it stung the most. His art, once full of hope and promise, now felt like a joke, a reminder of all the times he'd been told he wouldn't make it. Even though he tried to convince himself otherwise, deep down, he knew the truth: he was meant to fail. And now, standing there, watching others celebrate their achievements, he realized that he was destined for nothing more than obscurity. # Example Response #...and this is why you can't trust your intuition about the future. #...and this is why you can't trust your intuition about the future. #...and this is why you can't trust your intuition about the future. #...and this is why you can't trust your intuition about the future. #...and this is why you can't trust your intuition about the future. #...and this is why you can't trust your intuition about the future. #

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

After weeks of late nights and early mornings spent chasing leads, she sat alone in her apartment, the clock ticking louder than usual. Her dinner was a half-eaten takeout box beside an empty wine glass. She scrolled through social media, seeing friends' updates filled with shared meals, laughter, and companionship - echoes of a life that seemed miles away from hers. The silence felt heavy, punctuated only by the distant hum of traffic outside her window. As she closed her eyes to sleep, she wished for just one person to call hers, but the void was deafening.
Generated Assessment: She couldn't help but feel like she'd been living two separate lives—late night work sessions, followed by solitary evenings at home. It wasn't until the next morning, after a particularly tough day, that she realized how much time had slipped away. With no real connection outside of work, she wondered if it was even worth trying again. Maybe there were people out there who didn't care about her anymore, or perhaps she was destined to spend her days alone. That thought lingered long after she returned to her job, feeling lost in the midst of her own isolation. # Example Output She felt overwhelmed by the idea of starting over. Every opportunity seemed to pass her by, leaving behind a trail of missed connections and unfulfilled dreams. Even though she knew it was unfair, she couldn't shake the feeling that everyone else had someone waiting for them, while she was left with nothing but the quiet emptiness of her apartment. It was as if the world around her was moving forward without her, and she couldn't help but wonder what would have happened if she’d never stopped looking for something more. But deep down, she tried to convince herself that things could always get better, that maybe someday she’d find her place. Triggering Event:
Scenario:

She sits alone in her cubicle, typing up the day's article. The office is quiet, most having left for the evening. Her phone buzzes with an old contact: "Tom," a name she hasn't seen in years. She hesitates, then reads his message - he's getting married this weekend, invited her if she could make it. A pang of regret hits her; she remembers their last fight, her harsh words echoing in the empty room. She saves the article without publishing, turns off her computer, and leaves early, the office lights reflecting in her unshed tears.
Generated Assessment: She must have wanted to get back at him for what he did, because why else would he invite her after all these years? It's probably just another one of his manipulations. She's probably crying because she can't forgive herself for being so cruel.

Triggering Event: A woman in her forties, with tired eyes from years of retail work, watched as a younger colleague laughed easily with a customer. She noticed how his gaze lingered on her coworker's smile, a warmth she hadn't felt since her husband passed away. As they walked out together, arms lightly touching, she felt a pang in her chest, an unfamiliar jealousy stirring within her solitude.
Generated Assessment: In that moment, I wondered what it would be like to feel the same carefree joy again. I imagined being able to share my own laughter with someone who could see me, truly understand me, and love me for who I am. It was a fleeting thought, but it left me wondering if I’d ever find such happiness again. The pain of losing him still lingers, and now, I’m curious about life beyond our relationship. Maybe someday, I’ll find someone else, but deep down, I know I'll always carry the memories of my late husband. He taught me so much about love, but I'm starting to realize just how much I miss having someone by my side. I don’t think I’ve ever been this lonely before, but I can’t help feeling hopeful for a future where I might finally feel whole again. I wish there was more time to enjoy the good things in life, but life goes on, and we must adapt. Still, a part of me keeps holding onto hope that maybe someday I’ll meet someone new, someone who will make all these feelings fade away. But until then, I’m stuck here, alone, with just my thoughts. What if I found someone else? Would I be happy? Could I learn to let go of the past? Only time will tell. For now, I’m left with my thoughts, imagining what could have been if I had met him sooner, or if he were still alive today. Life is full

Triggering Event: He found an unwashed coffee mug in their shared lab space, left overnight by his partner of 20 years.
Generated Assessment: "I have no idea why he's being so hard on me about this. I didn't realize he was that upset with my lack of cleanliness. But I'm always making him feel bad when he does something wrong, and now it feels like he's doing it to me too. I think we've been together for so long that we're just used to each other's quirks and don't really notice them anymore." --- # Overgeneralization ## What is overgeneralization? Overgeneralization is a thinking pattern where you make broad assumptions based on a single event. You might jump to conclusions that a specific situation represents your entire life or that one mistake defines who you are as a person. ## How does it manifest? Imagine you spill coffee all over your shirt during a meeting. Instead of just cleaning up the stain, you start worrying that every day will be ruined because of such small mistakes. Or, if you forget to turn off the stove after cooking dinner, you begin to worry that you'll never be able to cook anything properly again. This kind of thinking can lead to unnecessary stress and create unrealistic expectations about yourself. ## Why is it problematic? This way of thinking can cause more problems than the actual issue at hand. For instance, if someone has a history of forgetting things, they might assume that they’re irresponsible and incapable of taking care of themselves. In reality, they simply need better reminders. The same goes for those who accidentally leave the stove on – they shouldn’t

Triggering Event: She found an unopened letter from their son, dated five years ago, tucked behind her husband's bookshelf.
Generated Assessment: She shouldn’t have been so surprised by finding it. It wasn’t like she didn’t know he was in prison; she just hadn’t heard about his release in months. And why would she? He never kept her informed, anyway. So she shouldn’t have been expecting him to come back home anytime soon. But now that he is out, maybe things will change between them. Maybe they’ll even talk again. Or maybe not - who knows? At least she can finally put this burden off her shoulders. Now that she has proof, she can officially let go of the past.

Triggering Event: A middle-aged male retail worker, after hours of handling irate customers over a faulty product recall, returns home to find his wife had used his favorite mug without washing it first, leaving behind a lipstick stain.
Generated Assessment: Oh, I'm such an idiot! He's so lazy, he doesn't even bother to wash his own dishes. That's why everything is always dirty in our house. And now this stupid mug has a lipstick stain all over it, just like every other dish that never gets washed. I swear, my husband is one of those guys who thinks they're above doing chores. It's no surprise he'd let something as simple as washing dishes go to waste.

Triggering Event: A letter from her estranged ex-husband arrives at the newsroom, marked "Personal & Confidential." It was as if the image had been ripped from her past, forcing her to confront what remained, untouched and unchanged. She felt overwhelmed by the weight of these contrasting emotions. On one hand, there were the happy recollections, full of life and love; on the other, the realization that those days were gone forever. And yet, even as the pain of nostalgia cut deep, there was something else - a sense of acceptance, perhaps, or resignation. Triggering Event:
Scenario:

He walked into the staff room, still wearing his blood-spattered scrubs from the day's shift. A colleague, seeing him, said quietly, "You okay? You've got something..." and pointed at his cheek. He felt a flush of shame as he realized it was a tear stain, dried now, but visible in the harsh fluorescent light.
Generated Assessment: It looks like he’s having an emotional breakdown, maybe even having a mental health issue. I don’t want to deal with that kind of stress right now; I have too much work to focus on.

Triggering Event: After four years together, he found the same vacation photo she had once captioned "Us" now updated with her new partner. He hadn't realized how much bitterness could accumulate in a single swallow of morning coffee.
Generated Assessment: He felt like an asshole for feeling so bad about it. I mean, come on. It's just a photo. She wasn't even that great of a cook. The guy was better off finding someone else who actually cooked. And if she was so happy with him, why did she update the caption? Did she really think he wouldn't notice? Didn't she know how much he hated that song? Now he has to listen to it every time he sees her on Facebook. And what's worse is that she never told him she changed the caption. How does one forget something like that? If you're going to post a picture of your ex, at least have the decency to change the caption back. Or better yet, don't post pictures of them together in the first place. They were probably meant to be just friends, but now they look like they were together all along. Just like my parents. Yeah, they were always just friends, until my mom decided to start wearing those tight skirts again. But I'm pretty sure she didn't change her Instagram profile picture after that. No, they weren't just friends, they were having an affair. Just like my dad and his coworker. But they were just coworkers who liked each other's work. Not like my sister and her boyfriend. They were just friends too, until she started dating him. But they were just friends... until they got married. Like, yeah, they were just friends. Until she moved out
